abstract.text: A portable X-ray detector has been developed to complement "cold fusion" studies. Our reasoning is that any set of nuclear reactions which produce measurable heat must also produce abundant secondary \	extbf{x} -rays. However, at the Nagoya meeting and elsewhere, we found that errors and uncertainties in current cxperiments prewent unambiguous interpretation of claims of excess-heat gencration. Hence, this paper also outlines criteria for establishing calorimeter performance for definitive measurements of "excess hear" in cold-fusion experiments.

body_text.text: Nuclear reactions are characterized by relcase of MeV-scale energics, hence their importance to power-production schemes. (Chemical reactions typically involve eV-energies, down by a factor of 10* from nuclear reactions.) But energy release at the nuclear level implies that secondary x-rays will be produced, since only tens of keV are required to generate x-rays. If nuclear reactions are indeed producing heat at the lewels claimed $( > 1 \\\mathrm{m W} ),$ then sufficient x-rays should be produced to be detectable. The x-rays arnise from the ionizing eifects of nuclear products on the materials in which the heat dewelops. Thus, x-ray measurements may provide a crucial test for the presence of heat-generating nuclear reactions.

The energy of the x-rays provides iniormation on what reactions are taking place. (For example, if the Ru K-alpha line at 19.2 KeV is strong, onc may surmise the production of Ru.) A Monte Carlo computer code was written in order to estimate the number of x-rays detected near an electrolytic cell in which one of several fusion reactions occur. The cell is assumed to be cylindrical in shape, to have glass walls, and to contain a cylindrical palladium (or nickel) electrode immersed in DyO. The number of x-rays detected per fusion event is calculated.

First a fusion site is determined. This site is randomly selected from points within the specified skin thickness of the palladium clcctrode. (End effects are ncglected.) The skin thickness may be set to the clectrode radius in order to model fusion events occurring uniformly throughout the volume of the electrode.

Then the direction of the first outgoing charged particle is randomly selected and the particle is stepped through the palladium rod. At cach step the energy is calculated using the proton stopping powers of Zeigler, Biersack, and Littmark, The stopping and ranges of ions in maner, Pergamon Press, New York (1985). The stopping powers of other ions are determined from proton walues by using $z^{2}$ scaling. At each step, the K-shell ionization cross section is calculated using ECPSSR cross sections from Chen and Crasemann, At. Dara ond Nucl. Data Tobies, 33, 217, and Chen from Johansson and Campbell, PIXE. Wiley, New York (1988). The x-ray production cross section is then calculated by multiplying the ionization cross-section by the fluorescence yield. The cross section for ions other than protons is determined by taking $2^{2}$ times the proton cross setion for the same energy per nucleon.

From the cross section, an x-ray production probability is determined. Since the cross sections are very small, the probability is augmentod $b y$ a suitable factor which is later divided out of the results. (This is wquivalent to making cach "cvent" correspond to a large number of identical fusion ewents.) On the basis of this probability, it is determined at cach step whether or not an x-ray is emitted.

If an x-ray is emitted it is determined if the x-ray is a K-a or K-B x-ray on the basis of the B/a ratio. The direction of travel is then randomly chosen. The x-ray is followed along this direction through the electrode. $\\\mathbf{D_{2} O}$ and glass to the detector. Each event is then given a weight corresponding to th rall attenuation factor. The sum of such weights then represents the total (fractional) number of detected x-rays.
Since K-a and K-B x-rays have different attenuation factors, they are summed separately so as to provide an estimate of the numbers detected in cach peak.

Whether or not an x-ray is emitted at a given step, the ion continues its path through the electrodc. Each ion is then followed until it stops or leaves the clcctrode,. the possibility of x-ray emission being considered at cach step. If more than one charged particle is produced in the fusion ewent, the second particle is tracked in a similar fashion.

The calorimetrist has the responsibility to conclusively demonstrate the accuracy and precision of the heat measurements. Accurate heat measurement is far from trivial and nothing should be, assumed without good justifcation. Experience shows that gross errors can occur from obscure and difficult to detct effects.

body_text.text: A precise and complete description of how the calorimeter functions must be given together with a detailed physical description of the instrument. The physical description must include materials and accurate dimensions for all calorimeter components. The functional description must include the method of heat measurement and a description of the calorimeter system and surroundings.
body_text.section: OUTLINE OF FOR PERFORMANCEFOR MEASUREMENT OF"EXCESS HEAT INCOLD-FUSION EXPERIMENTS

body_text.text: $\\\mathbf{A}$ There are three methods of heat measurement.
body_text.section: OUTLINE OF FOR PERFORMANCEFOR MEASUREMENT OF"EXCESS HEAT INCOLD-FUSION EXPERIMENTS

body_text.text: 1. In the heat conduction method, the temperature difference across a thermal path with constant thermal conductivity between the system and surroundings is measured. This temperature difference is linearly proportional to the rate of heat flow through the path (Newton's law of cooling). For accurate mcasurement as much as possible of the heat flow must be through the measurement path. All other heat flow paths must also have a constant thermal conductivity.

back_matter.text: *Excess heat" can only be proven to be nuclear in origin by showing that the products of the nuclear reactions are produced at the same time and rate as the heat and in amounts commensurate with the law of mass-energy conservation. X-rays would, however, be a strong indicator of nucicar (MeV-scaic) reactions and would be an effective tracer of high-energy reactions when the precise nature of the processes remains hidden. Until such proof exists, application of Occam's razor demands that "excess heat" be regarded as having its source in ordinary chemical reactions.
